comments:
See bug # https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=50448

The <?eclipse version="3.0"?> line without having "runtime compatibility" as a
required plugin can cause your GEFPlugin class to try to be instantiated with
default ctor, which you don't have. This causes stack traces and the GEFPlugin
will not be initialized.

As you can see from the bug referenced above, unless you are going to be a
full-blown OSGi bundle, it is best to simply remove the version=3.0 line.

The way this occurred for me was I was accessing a class in my plugin that
inherited from a GEF class. Upon the load of the GEF class it tried to start the
GEFPlugin up as an OSGi bundle in new mode, and not in old mode. And it threw an
exception.

Thanks Rich.  We aware of this problem which is introduced if you use 
integration builds after M6 (0128 I think).  It's funny how they make these 
world changes and you'd better be subscribed to the right mailing list if you 
want your code to work!

Are you able to reproduce any bugs using the correct dependencies specified 
from the GEF download page?  If not, this should be closed since a solution is 
already in HEAD.

I'm using GEF driver I20040210 with Eclipse driver I20040209. This Eclipse
driver is actually up-level from the driver specified on the GEF download page
(GEF is specifying the six-week old M6 driver on the GEF download page).

And yes, the problem occurs with this combination.

When I manually removed the <eclipse... version=> line, everything came up fine.
No problems. With them in as it is built, you get this error when bringing up
the visual editor:

org.osgi.framework.BundleException: The BundleActivator
org.eclipse.gef.GEFPlugin is invalid
	at
org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.Bundle.loadBundleActivator(Bundle.java:176)
	at
org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContext.start(BundleContext.java:987)
	at
org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleHost.startWorker(BundleHost.java:403)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.Bundle.start(Bundle.java:312)
	at
org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseClassLoader.findLocalClass(EclipseClassLoader.java:58)

Also, instead of removing the 3.0, adding runtime compatibility will be
sufficient too, which is what I believe you had done, you added the runtime
compatibility. Can you get a GEF build out immediately with this change so that
we can use it without having to manually change the plugin.xml files?

Thanks,
Rich
The I20040212 build has the fix
*** Bug 52124 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
